comment_text.dn26:1.2: Mātulā means “maternal uncle”. This Magadhan village is mentioned only here and Cp 9:39.2.
comment_text.dn26:1.14: Two parables on mindfulness expand this idea (SN 47.6, SN 46.7).
comment_text.dn26:1.16: Evamidaṁ indicates entailment, as at SN 56.21:1.3, MN 73:13.2, DN 16:4.2.4.
comment_text.dn26:2.1: We have heard the story of the wheel-turning monarch Mahāsudassana in DN 17. Daḷhanemi appears only here. His name means “Strong-rim”, such being one of the characteristics of the Wheel. His story of renunciation shares much in common with that of Maghadeva (MN 83).
comment_text.dn26:3.2: “Receded back” (osakkitaṁ): like a woman shrinking away from a man’s unwanted advances (DN 12:16.12).
comment_text.dn26:3.10: The same point of view is expressed at Bi Pc 21:1.4, where sex workers teased nuns, suggesting they enjoy themselves while young and ordain when old. The Buddhist position is that Dhamma can be practiced at any age.
comment_text.dn26:3.13: The signs of the renunciate predate Buddhism.
comment_text.dn26:4.4: The “royal seer” (rājisi, Sanskrit rājarṣi) is described by Kauṭilya (Arthaśāstra 1.7.1). Such a king should pursue pleasures in moderation, rely on good advice, and work energetically for the welfare and prosperity of his people.
comment_text.dn26:4.7: “Inherited from your father” (pettikaṁ dāyajjaṁ) calls back to the four satipaṭṭhānas that for a mendicant are “the domain of your fathers” (pettike visaye). In both cases they are to be earned, not conferred by lineage.
comment_text.dn26:4.8: “The noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch” (ariye cakkavattivatte; this is locative singular). Ariya (“noble”) qualifies “duty” (vatta), as it does in the title below, cakkavattiariyavatta, rather than “monarch”. Normally ariya is reserved for those who have attained the Buddhist path, but here we might have a rare use of ariya in reference to Indo-Aryan (Vedic) culture. Compare the use of ariyaka for Indo-Aryan language (Bu Pj 1:8.4.10), and ariyaṁ āyatanaṁ for the “civilized region” (DN 16:1.28.7, AN 6.96:1.3, Ud 8.6:17.9). However, the commentary says it simply means “flawless” (niddoso).
comment_text.dn26:5.2: Saṁvidahassu is second middle imperative.
comment_text.dn26:5.3: Pavattittha is aorist middle. (A)dhammakāra (“(in)justice”) doesn’t seem to occur elsewhere in early Pali. It is found in Ja 513 and Ja 498, both times in the context of just rule.
comment_text.dn26:5.4: “Provide” (anuppadeti) is used elsewhere in the sense of paying back a loan (AN 3.20:3.5), serving honored guests (SN 7.2:2.6), paying wages (DN 31:32.2), or a king supplying provisions for essential workers to do their job (DN 5:11.8). It is thus more about fulfilling a moral obligation of fairness than offering charity.
comment_text.dn26:5.5: Where the phrase “from time to time go to them” (te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā) occurs elsewhere in the suttas, it is always followed by “ask and question” (paripucchati paripañhati). Here, however, the second verb is “you should learn” (pariggaṇheyyāsi).
comment_text.dn26:9.6: Pabbanti is unusual and probably unique in early Pali. It is related to Sanskrit parvati (“fill”) and is explained by the commentary as vaḍḍhanti (“grow, prosper”). | I assume janapadā (“countries”) is a misspelling of jānapadā (“people of the country”), as janapada is otherwise in singular.
comment_text.dn26:9.7: “Military officers” (anīkaṭṭhā) would have been standing officers in the army. According to both the commentary here and Monier-Williams’ Sanskrit Dictionary (anīkastha), it includes elephant officers, who would have stood at the head of the army. | “Professional advisers” (mantassājīvino) is explained by the commentary as those who make a living from giving wise advice.
comment_text.dn26:10.3: Ensuring citizens have enough to live on is not merely a matter of kindness and common decency, but is crucial to ensure stability and national unity.
comment_text.dn26:10.5: The origins of theft are told at DN 27:19.1. The myth recounted here overlaps, with points of both similarity and difference.
comment_text.dn26:10.10: The king uses the same procedure as the Buddha. When presented with an alleged wrong-doer, the first thing is to ask them whether they did it.
comment_text.dn26:10.15: Simply providing money is not enough, nor is simply expecting that people can just work for what they want. They need something to get started, together with the support and opportunity to build a life for themselves.
comment_text.dn26:12.2: Sadly, bad faith actors take advantage of kindness.
comment_text.dn26:12.16: While the king’s concern is legitimate, his overreaction escalates the problems.
comment_text.dn26:13.4: The violence of the state leads to an armed and violent citizenry.
comment_text.dn26:14.2: Today we can see that, even among developed nations, a degraded and violent culture leads to declining lifespans.
comment_text.dn26:17.2: Paresaṁ dāresu: both “others” and “wives” are in plural, so polygyny is assumed. Compare parassa dāresu (“the wives of another”) at SN 55.7:6.3. Note the significance granted to beauty in influencing human society.
comment_text.dn26:17.6: At this point, the three factors of wrong action—killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct—are present, as are the four factors of wrong speech—lying, backbiting, harsh speech, and nonsensical speech.
comment_text.dn26:17.12: This completes the three factors of unskillful thought: desire, ill will, and wrong views (which are a strong form of delusion). Here wrong view probably means moral nihilism.
comment_text.dn26:17.16: These three terms recur in a similar context at AN 3.56:2.1. The commentaries to the two passages give quite different explanations. | “Illicit desire” (adhammarāgo) probably refers to any form of desire that is illegal or transgressive, such as incest, rape, or pedophilia. | “Immoral greed” (visamalobho) implies excess and imbalance. Both are, however, explained in the commentary to AN 3.56:2.1 as desire for the belongings of others. | Micchādhammo is hard to pin down. Its opposite, sammā dhammo always means “right teaching”. The commentary here explains it as “men with men and women with women”, but this must be rejected as there is no hint anywhere in early Pali (or elsewhere in early Indian culture) that homosexual relations were considered immoral. The commentary to AN 3.56:2.1 explains it as “indulgence in what is reckoned an inappropriate basis” (avatthupaṭisevanasaṅkhātena). This implies intercourse with one of the women mentioned at MN 41:8.4, which includes those who are “protected by principle” (dhammarakkhitā). This sense of dhamma is explained at Bu Ss 5:4.2.16 as “religion”. Here I think the sense is similar: customs or beliefs that legitimize immorality.
comment_text.dn26:18.14: This brings us to the Buddha’s present.
comment_text.dn26:19.1: Here the Buddha paints a devastating picture of societal collapse. Life expectancy as low as thirty years has been recorded in some countries in the 20th century.
comment_text.dn26:19.2: The age of onset of puberty has been dropping globally over the past century, with isolated cases as young as five.
comment_text.dn26:19.5: “Finger millet” (kudrūsaka; Pahari kodra, Garhwal koda) is a robust secondary grain in Asia and Africa, growing in places rice cannot. Due to its resilience in the face of global heating, 2023 was declared the International Year of Millets by the UN.
comment_text.dn26:19.6: The Buddha’s father gave this luxury food to servants and staff (AN 3.39:2.3).
comment_text.dn26:19.8: The narrative above traced the gradual disappearance of these ten factors. | Atibyādippissanti is a unique term. At AN 7.66:9.2 a sign of the end of days is the “erupting” (ādippanti) of volcanoes, suggesting “explode” for the intensive form here.
comment_text.dn26:19.9: “Skillful” is kusala, otherwise translated as “good” or “wholesome”.
comment_text.dn26:20.1: At AN 2.9 = Iti 42 the world is protected from this by conscience and prudence.
comment_text.dn26:20.2: For sambheda in the sense of “dissolving, leaking”, see DN 3:1.15.11, AN 5.103:6.4, AN 10.45:4.1. The commentary here says “mixedness, breaking of boundaries”.
comment_text.dn26:21.1: “Interregnum of swords” is satthantarakappo. Seven days seems optimistic.
comment_text.dn26:21.2: Dehumanization of the other is an essential precursor to genocide.
comment_text.dn26:21.6: “Let us neither kill nor be killed” (mā ca mayaṁ kañci, mā ca amhe koci) is an idiomatic phrase, the Golden Rule framed as a negative: “Let us not do unto others nor let others do unto us.” It is explained by the commentary as, “Let us not take even a single person’s life or let them take ours”.
comment_text.dn26:21.8: Sabhāgāyissanti = sabhāga + āyissanti = “will come together”. | Samassāsissanti = sama + sāsati = “cry in one voice”. The latter term is absent from some manuscripts.
comment_text.dn26:21.9: Diṭṭhā is Sanskrit diṣṭyā, “fantastic, how fortunate”, per DN 16:2.24.5 and Ja 81:1.4. | Sattā is nominative singular for sattar (“enemy”), not plural of satta (“being”), which disagrees with both verb and vocative in number.
comment_text.dn26:21.15: The first precept, and the first of the ten ways of skillful action. The Buddhist ethical principles are not just a part of Buddhist teaching, they are essential for the healthy functioning of human society.
comment_text.dn26:23.5: In the legendary past, too, only these three afflictions prevailed (Snp 2.7:29.1).
comment_text.dn26:25.1: This is the only sutta appearance of the future Buddha Metteyya (Sanskrit Maitreya, meaning “one full of love”). He became a prominent figure in later Buddhism.
comment_text.dn26:25.2: Throughout, the Buddha is concerned to emphasize that the future Buddha will offer no more or less than his own teaching and practice. He wanted people to practice now, not to establish a cult of a future savior.
comment_text.dn26:25.6: The maximum number of monastics cited in the suttas is 1250 at a single gathering.
comment_text.dn26:26.1: This event is found in Bhaddaji’s verses at Thag 2.22, expanded to a full story at Ja 264. The commentary explains yūpa as “palace”, but Bhaddaji’s verses clearly depict a sacrificial post, to which the animal would be tied for slaughter. Such posts are connected with the horse sacrifice, which establishes imperial power. This is but one aspect of the wheel-turning monarch to draw on imagery from the horse sacrifice. Here, of course, no horses are killed.
comment_text.dn26:26.2: Ajjhāvasati in this sutta means “reign” not “dwell” (DN 26:2.5).

root_text.dn26:1.15: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṁ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṁ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṁ.

root_text.dn26:2.1: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi nāma ahosi cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
root_text.dn26:2.3: cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
root_text.dn26:2.4: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā ahesuṁ sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
root_text.dn26:2.5: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasi.
root_text.dn26:3.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn26:3.2: ‘yadā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, passeyyāsi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, atha me āroceyyāsī’ti.
root_text.dn26:3.3: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño daḷhanemissa paccassosi.
root_text.dn26:3.4: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so puriso bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, disvāna yena rājā daḷhanemi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ daḷhanemiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:3.5: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ te cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutan’ti.
root_text.dn26:3.6: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:3.7: ‘dibbaṁ kira me, tāta kumāra, cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ.
root_text.dn26:3.9: yassa rañño cakkavattissa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkati ṭhānā cavati, na dāni tena raññā ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ hotīti.
root_text.dn26:3.10: Bhuttā kho pana me mānusakā kāmā, samayo dāni me dibbe kāme pariyesituṁ.
root_text.dn26:3.11: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta kumāra, imaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ paṭipajja.
root_text.dn26:3.12: Ahaṁ pana kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmī’ti.
root_text.dn26:3.13: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
root_text.dn26:3.14: Sattāhapabbajite kho pana, bhikkhave, rājisimhi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antaradhāyi.
root_text.dn26:4.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso yena rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:4.3: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi, anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi.
root_text.dn26:4.4: So yena rājisi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājisiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:4.6: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājisi rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:4.7: ‘mā kho tvaṁ, tāta, dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi, mā anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi, na hi te, tāta, dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pettikaṁ dāyajjaṁ.
root_text.dn26:4.8: Iṅgha tvaṁ, tāta, ariye cakkavattivatte vattāhi.
root_text.dn26:4.9: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ te ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pātubhavissati sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūran’ti.
root_text.dn26:5.2: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
root_text.dn26:5.3: Mā ca te, tāta, vijite adhammakāro pavattittha.
root_text.dn26:5.4: Ye ca te, tāta, vijite adhanā assu, tesañca dhanamanuppadeyyāsi.
root_text.dn26:5.5: Ye ca te, tāta, vijite samaṇabrāhmaṇā madappamādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṁ damenti, ekamattānaṁ samenti, ekamattānaṁ parinibbāpenti, te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā paripuccheyyāsi pariggaṇheyyāsi:

root_text.dn26:5.7: Tesaṁ sutvā yaṁ akusalaṁ taṁ abhinivajjeyyāsi, yaṁ kusalaṁ taṁ samādāya vatteyyāsi.

root_text.dn26:7.15: Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:7.16: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, cakkaratanaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ abhivijinitvā tameva rājadhāniṁ paccāgantvā rañño cakkavattissa antepuradvāre atthakaraṇapamukhe akkhāhataṁ maññe aṭṭhāsi rañño cakkavattissa antepuraṁ upasobhayamānaṁ.
root_text.dn26:8.6: sattamopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn26:8.7: ‘yadā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, passeyyāsi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, atha me āroceyyāsī’ti.
root_text.dn26:8.8: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño cakkavattissa paccassosi.
root_text.dn26:8.9: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so puriso bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ.
root_text.dn26:8.10: Disvāna yena rājā cakkavattī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ cakkavattiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:8.11: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ te cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutan’ti?
root_text.dn26:8.12: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:8.13: ‘dibbaṁ kira me, tāta kumāra, cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ, ṭhānā cutaṁ, sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ—
root_text.dn26:8.14: yassa rañño cakkavattissa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkati, ṭhānā cavati, na dāni tena raññā ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ hotīti.
root_text.dn26:8.15: Bhuttā kho pana me mānusakā kāmā, samayo dāni me dibbe kāme pariyesituṁ, ehi tvaṁ, tāta kumāra, imaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ paṭipajja.
root_text.dn26:8.16: Ahaṁ pana kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmī’ti.
root_text.dn26:8.17: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
root_text.dn26:8.18: Sattāhapabbajite kho pana, bhikkhave, rājisimhi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antaradhāyi.
root_text.dn26:9.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso yena rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:9.3: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi. Anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi;
root_text.dn26:9.4: no ca kho rājisiṁ upasaṅkamitvā ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ pucchi.
root_text.dn26:9.6: Tassa samatena janapadaṁ pasāsato pubbenāparaṁ janapadā na pabbanti, yathā taṁ pubbakānaṁ rājūnaṁ ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānānaṁ.
root_text.dn26:9.7: Atha kho, bhikkhave, amaccā pārisajjā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā mantassājīvino sannipatitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn26:9.8: ‘na kho te, deva, samatena sudaṁ janapadaṁ pasāsato pubbenāparaṁ janapadā pabbanti, yathā taṁ pubbakānaṁ rājūnaṁ ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānānaṁ.
root_text.dn26:9.9: Saṁvijjanti kho te, deva, vijite amaccā pārisajjā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā mantassājīvino mayañceva aññe ca ye mayaṁ ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ dhārema.
root_text.dn26:9.10: Iṅgha tvaṁ, deva, amhe ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puccha.
root_text.dn26:9.11: Tassa te mayaṁ ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puṭṭhā byākarissāmā’ti.
root_text.dn26:10.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto amacce pārisajje gaṇakamahāmatte anīkaṭṭhe dovārike mantassājīvino sannipātetvā ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ pucchi.
root_text.dn26:10.2: Tassa te ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puṭṭhā byākariṁsu.
root_text.dn26:10.3: Tesaṁ sutvā dhammikañhi kho rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahi, no ca kho adhanānaṁ dhanamanuppadāsi.
root_text.dn26:10.5: Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
root_text.dn26:10.8: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
root_text.dn26:10.9: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:10.10: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
root_text.dn26:10.14: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tassa purisassa dhanamanuppadāsi:
root_text.dn26:10.15: ‘iminā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, dhanena attanā ca jīvāhi, mātāpitaro ca posehi, puttadārañca posehi, kammante ca payojehi, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhāpehi sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikan’ti.
root_text.dn26:10.16: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paccassosi.
root_text.dn26:11.1: Aññataropi kho, bhikkhave, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
root_text.dn26:11.4: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
root_text.dn26:11.5: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:11.6: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
root_text.dn26:11.10: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tassa purisassa dhanamanuppadāsi:
root_text.dn26:11.11: ‘iminā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, dhanena attanā ca jīvāhi, mātāpitaro ca posehi, puttadārañca posehi, kammante ca payojehi, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhāpehi sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikan’ti.
root_text.dn26:11.12: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paccassosi.
root_text.dn26:12.2: ‘ye kira, bho, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, tesaṁ rājā dhanamanuppadetī’ti.
root_text.dn26:12.5: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
root_text.dn26:12.8: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
root_text.dn26:12.9: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:12.10: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
root_text.dn26:12.14: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn26:12.15: ‘sace kho ahaṁ yo yo paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyissati, tassa tassa dhanamanuppadassāmi, evamidaṁ adinnādānaṁ pavaḍḍhissati.
root_text.dn26:12.16: Yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ purisaṁ sunisedhaṁ nisedheyyaṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ kareyyaṁ, sīsamassa chindeyyan’ti.
root_text.dn26:12.17: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto purise āṇāpesi:
root_text.dn26:12.18: ‘tena hi, bhaṇe, imaṁ purisaṁ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sunisedhaṁ nisedhetha, mūlaghaccaṁ karotha, sīsamassa chindathā’ti.
root_text.dn26:12.19: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, te purisā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sunisedhaṁ nisedhesuṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ akaṁsu, sīsamassa chindiṁsu.
root_text.dn26:13.2: ‘ye kira, bho, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, te rājā sunisedhaṁ nisedheti, mūlaghaccaṁ karoti, sīsāni tesaṁ chindatī’ti.
root_text.dn26:13.4: ‘yannūna mayampi tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpessāma, tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā yesaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyissāma, te sunisedhaṁ nisedhessāma, mūlaghaccaṁ karissāma, sīsāni tesaṁ chindissāmā’ti.
root_text.dn26:13.5: Te tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpesuṁ, tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā gāmaghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, nigamaghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, nagaraghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, panthaduhanampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ.
root_text.dn26:13.6: Yesaṁ te adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, te sunisedhaṁ nisedhenti, mūlaghaccaṁ karonti, sīsāni tesaṁ chindanti.
root_text.dn26:14.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi, dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi, satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:14.2: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ asītivassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:14.3: Cattārīsavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
root_text.dn26:14.6: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
root_text.dn26:14.7: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn26:14.8: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
root_text.dn26:15.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate musāvādo vepullamagamāsi, musāvāde vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:15.2: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ cattārīsavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsativassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:15.3: Vīsativassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
root_text.dn26:15.4: Tamenaṁ aññataro puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa ārocesi:
root_text.dn26:15.5: ‘itthannāmo, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti pesuññamakāsi.
root_text.dn26:16.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi, satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate musāvādo vepullamagamāsi, musāvāde vepullaṁ gate pisuṇā vācā vepullamagamāsi, pisuṇāya vācāya vepullaṁ gatāya tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:16.2: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ vīsativassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ dasavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.1: Dasavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ekidaṁ sattā vaṇṇavanto honti, ekidaṁ sattā dubbaṇṇā.
root_text.dn26:17.2: Tattha ye te sattā dubbaṇṇā, te vaṇṇavante satte abhijjhāyantā paresaṁ dāresu cārittaṁ āpajjiṁsu.
root_text.dn26:17.3: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate …pe… kāmesumicchācāro vepullamagamāsi, kāmesumicchācāre vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:17.4: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ dasavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ pañcavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.5: Pañcavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu dve dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu—
root_text.dn26:17.7: Dvīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:17.8: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ pañcavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ appekacce aḍḍhateyyavassasahassāyukā, appekacce dvevassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.10: Abhijjhābyāpādesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:17.11: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ aḍḍhateyyavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.13: Micchādiṭṭhiyā vepullaṁ gatāya tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:17.14: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ vassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ pañcavassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.15: Pañcavassasatāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tayo dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu—
root_text.dn26:17.17: Tīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:17.18: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ pañcavassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ appekacce aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukā, appekacce dvevassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:17.19: Aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ime dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu.
root_text.dn26:17.20: Amatteyyatā apetteyyatā asāmaññatā abrahmaññatā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitā.
root_text.dn26:18.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi.
root_text.dn26:18.6: Musāvāde vepullaṁ gate pisuṇā vācā vepullamagamāsi.
root_text.dn26:18.7: Pisuṇāya vācāya vepullaṁ gatāya kāmesumicchācāro vepullamagamāsi.
root_text.dn26:18.8: Kāmesumicchācāre vepullaṁ gate dve dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, pharusā vācā samphappalāpo ca.
root_text.dn26:18.9: Dvīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu abhijjhābyāpādā vepullamagamaṁsu.
root_text.dn26:18.11: Micchādiṭṭhiyā vepullaṁ gatāya tayo dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, adhammarāgo visamalobho micchādhammo.
root_text.dn26:18.12: Tīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu ime dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, amatteyyatā apetteyyatā asāmaññatā abrahmaññatā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitā.
root_text.dn26:18.13: Imesu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
root_text.dn26:18.14: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn26:19.1: Bhavissati, bhikkhave, so samayo, yaṁ imesaṁ manussānaṁ dasavassāyukā puttā bhavissanti.
root_text.dn26:19.2: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu pañcavassikā kumārikā alaṁpateyyā bhavissanti.
root_text.dn26:19.3: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu imāni rasāni antaradhāyissanti, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.dn26:19.4: sappi navanītaṁ telaṁ madhu phāṇitaṁ loṇaṁ.
root_text.dn26:19.5: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu kudrūsako aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ bhavissati.
root_text.dn26:19.6: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, etarahi sālimaṁsodano aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ;
root_text.dn26:19.7: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu kudrūsako aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ bhavissati.
root_text.dn26:19.8: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu dasa kusalakammapathā sabbena sabbaṁ antaradhāyissanti, dasa akusalakammapathā atibyādippissanti.
root_text.dn26:19.9: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu kusalantipi na bhavissati, kuto pana kusalassa kārako.
root_text.dn26:19.10: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ye te bhavissanti amatteyyā apetteyyā asāmaññā abrahmaññā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, te pujjā ca bhavissanti pāsaṁsā ca.
root_text.dn26:19.11: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, etarahi matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino pujjā ca pāsaṁsā ca;
root_text.dn26:19.12: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu ye te bhavissanti amatteyyā apetteyyā asāmaññā abrahmaññā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, te pujjā ca bhavissanti pāsaṁsā ca.
root_text.dn26:20.1: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu na bhavissati mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṁ dārāti vā.
root_text.dn26:20.2: Sambhedaṁ loko gamissati yathā ajeḷakā kukkuṭasūkarā soṇasiṅgālā.
root_text.dn26:20.3: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ aññamaññamhi tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
root_text.dn26:20.6: bhātupi bhaginiyā bhaginiyāpi bhātari tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
root_text.dn26:20.7: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, māgavikassa migaṁ disvā tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito hoti tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ;
root_text.dn26:20.8: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ aññamaññamhi tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
root_text.dn26:20.11: bhātupi bhaginiyā bhaginiyāpi bhātari tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
root_text.dn26:21.1: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu sattāhaṁ satthantarakappo bhavissati.
root_text.dn26:21.4: Te tiṇhena satthena ‘esa migo esa migo’ti aññamaññaṁ jīvitā voropessanti.
root_text.dn26:21.5: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ ekaccānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
root_text.dn26:21.6: ‘mā ca mayaṁ kañci, mā ca amhe koci, yannūna mayaṁ tiṇagahanaṁ vā vanagahanaṁ vā rukkhagahanaṁ vā nadīviduggaṁ vā pabbatavisamaṁ vā pavisitvā vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn26:21.7: Te tiṇagahanaṁ vā vanagahanaṁ vā rukkhagahanaṁ vā nadīviduggaṁ vā pabbatavisamaṁ vā pavisitvā sattāhaṁ vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpessanti.
root_text.dn26:21.8: Te tassa sattāhassa accayena tiṇagahanā vanagahanā rukkhagahanā nadīviduggā pabbatavisamā nikkhamitvā aññamaññaṁ āliṅgitvā sabhāgāyissanti samassāsissanti:
root_text.dn26:21.9: ‘diṭṭhā, bho, sattā jīvasi, diṭṭhā, bho, sattā jīvasī’ti.
root_text.dn26:21.11: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
root_text.dn26:21.12: ‘mayaṁ kho akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu evarūpaṁ āyataṁ ñātikkhayaṁ pattā.
root_text.dn26:21.15: Yannūna mayaṁ pāṇātipātā virameyyāma, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vatteyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn26:21.16: Te pāṇātipātā viramissanti, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vattissanti.
root_text.dn26:21.17: Te kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhissanti, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissanti.
root_text.dn26:21.18: Tesaṁ āyunāpi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ dasavassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsativassāyukā puttā bhavissanti.
root_text.dn26:22.1: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
root_text.dn26:22.2: ‘mayaṁ kho kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhāma, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhāma.
root_text.dn26:22.3: Yannūna mayaṁ bhiyyoso mattāya kusalaṁ kareyyāma.
root_text.dn26:22.16: yannūna mayaṁ matteyyā assāma petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vatteyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn26:22.17: Te matteyyā bhavissanti petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vattissanti.
root_text.dn26:22.18: Te kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhissanti, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissanti.
root_text.dn26:22.19: Tesaṁ āyunāpi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vīsativassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsavassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
root_text.dn26:23.3: asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu pañcavassasatikā kumārikā alaṁpateyyā bhavissanti.
root_text.dn26:23.5: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tayo ābādhā bhavissanti, icchā, anasanaṁ, jarā.
root_text.dn26:23.6: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ jambudīpo iddho ceva bhavissati phīto ca, kukkuṭasampātikā gāmanigamarājadhāniyo.
root_text.dn26:23.7: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ jambudīpo avīci maññe phuṭo bhavissati manussehi, seyyathāpi naḷavanaṁ vā saravanaṁ vā.
root_text.dn26:23.8: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ bārāṇasī ketumatī nāma rājadhānī bhavissati iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
root_text.dn26:23.9: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu imasmiṁ jambudīpe caturāsītinagarasahassāni bhavissanti ketumatīrājadhānīpamukhāni.
root_text.dn26:24.1: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ketumatiyā rājadhāniyā saṅkho nāma rājā uppajjissati cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
root_text.dn26:24.3: cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
root_text.dn26:24.4: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavissanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
root_text.dn26:24.5: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasissati.
root_text.dn26:25.1: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu metteyyo nāma bhagavā loke uppajjissati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.dn26:25.2: Seyyathāpāhametarahi loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.dn26:25.3: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedessati, seyyathāpāhametarahi imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedemi.
root_text.dn26:25.4: So dhammaṁ desessati ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāsessati;
root_text.dn26:25.5: seyyathāpāhametarahi dhammaṁ desemi ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāsemi.
root_text.dn26:25.6: So anekasahassaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pariharissati, seyyathāpāhametarahi anekasataṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pariharāmi.
root_text.dn26:26.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, saṅkho nāma rājā yo so yūpo raññā mahāpanādena kārāpito.
root_text.dn26:26.2: Taṁ yūpaṁ ussāpetvā ajjhāvasitvā taṁ datvā vissajjitvā samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṁ dānaṁ datvā metteyyassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati.
root_text.dn26:26.3: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati.
root_text.dn26:27.1: Attadīpā, bhikkhave, viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
root_text.dn26:27.2: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
root_text.dn26:27.3: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.dn26:27.6: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.dn26:27.7: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
root_text.dn26:28.1: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
root_text.dn26:28.2: Gocare, bhikkhave, carantā sake pettike visaye āyunāpi vaḍḍhissatha, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissatha, sukhenapi vaḍḍhissatha, bhogenapi vaḍḍhissatha, balenapi vaḍḍhissatha.
root_text.dn26:28.4: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti,
root_text.dn26:28.8: So imesaṁ catunnaṁ iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā ākaṅkhamāno kappaṁ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṁ vā.
root_text.dn26:28.11: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
root_text.dn26:28.14: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn26:28.20: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn26:28.23: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn26:28.26: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn26:28.28: Nāhaṁ, bhikkhave, aññaṁ ekabalampi samanupassāmi yaṁ evaṁ duppasahaṁ, yathayidaṁ, bhikkhave, mārabalaṁ.
root_text.dn26:28.29: Kusalānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ samādānahetu evamidaṁ puññaṁ pavaḍḍhatī”ti.
root_text.dn26:28.31: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.dn26:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Mātulā.
translation_text.dn26:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.dn26:1.7: “Mendicants, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn26:1.8: And how does a mendicant do this?
translation_text.dn26:1.9: They meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn26:1.10: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.dn26:1.12: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn26:1.13: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how they let the teaching be their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn26:1.14: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
translation_text.dn26:1.15: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t find a vulnerability or get an opportunity.
translation_text.dn26:1.16: It is due to undertaking skillful qualities that merit grows.
translation_text.dn26:2.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Daḷhanemi who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
translation_text.dn26:2.2: He had the following seven treasures:
translation_text.dn26:2.3: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
translation_text.dn26:2.4: He had over a thousand sons who were valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.dn26:2.5: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigned by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.dn26:3.1: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Daḷhanemi addressed one of his men,
translation_text.dn26:3.2: ‘My good man, when you see that the heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place, please tell me.’
translation_text.dn26:3.4: After many thousand years had passed, that man saw that the heavenly wheel-treasure had receded back from its place. So he went to King Daḷhanemi and said,
translation_text.dn26:3.5: ‘Please sire, you should know that your heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place.’
translation_text.dn26:3.6: So the king summoned the crown prince and said,
translation_text.dn26:3.7: ‘Dear prince, my heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place.
translation_text.dn26:3.9: when this happens to a wheel-turning monarch, he does not have long to live.
translation_text.dn26:3.10: I have enjoyed human pleasures. Now it is time for me to seek heavenly pleasures.
translation_text.dn26:3.11: Come, dear prince, rule this land surrounded by ocean!
translation_text.dn26:3.12: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
translation_text.dn26:3.13: And so, after carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Daḷhanemi shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn26:3.14: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.
translation_text.dn26:4.1: Then a certain man approached the newly anointed aristocrat king and said,
translation_text.dn26:4.2: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’
translation_text.dn26:4.3: At that the king was unhappy and experienced unhappiness.
translation_text.dn26:4.4: He went to the royal seer and said,
translation_text.dn26:4.5: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’
translation_text.dn26:4.6: When he said this, the royal seer said to him,
translation_text.dn26:4.7: ‘Don’t be unhappy at the vanishing of the wheel-treasure. My dear, the wheel-treasure is not inherited from your father.
translation_text.dn26:4.8: Come now, my dear, proceed in the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:4.9: If you do so, it’s possible that—on a fifteenth day sabbath, having bathed your head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath—the heavenly wheel-treasure will appear to you, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.’
translation_text.dn26:5.0: 2.1. The Noble Duty of a Wheel-Turning Monarch
translation_text.dn26:5.1: ‘But sire, what is the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch?’
translation_text.dn26:5.2: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
translation_text.dn26:5.3: Do not let injustice prevail in the realm.
translation_text.dn26:5.4: Provide money to the penniless in the realm.
translation_text.dn26:5.5: And there are ascetics and brahmins in the realm who refrain from intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves. From time to time you should go up to them and ask and learn:
translation_text.dn26:5.6: “Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?”
translation_text.dn26:5.7: Having heard them, you should shun what is unskillful and undertake and follow what is skillful.
translation_text.dn26:5.8: This is the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.’
translation_text.dn26:5.10: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the new king to the royal seer. And he proceeded in the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:5.11: While he was proceeding in that duty, on a fifteenth day sabbath, he had bathed his head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
translation_text.dn26:5.12: And the heavenly wheel-treasure appeared to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.
translation_text.dn26:5.14: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:5.15: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’
translation_text.dn26:6.1: Then the anointed king, rising from his seat and arranging his robe over one shoulder, took a ceremonial vase in his left hand and besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying,
translation_text.dn26:6.2: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’
translation_text.dn26:6.3: Then the wheel-treasure rolled towards the east. And the king followed it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
translation_text.dn26:6.4: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to the wheel-turning monarch and said,
translation_text.dn26:6.5: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
translation_text.dn26:6.7: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
translation_text.dn26:6.8: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter became his vassals.
translation_text.dn26:7.1: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolled towards the south. …
translation_text.dn26:7.2: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the west. …
translation_text.dn26:7.9: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions.
translation_text.dn26:7.10: In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
translation_text.dn26:7.11: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to the wheel-turning monarch and said,
translation_text.dn26:7.12: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
translation_text.dn26:7.14: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
translation_text.dn26:7.15: And so the rulers of the northern quarter became his vassals.
translation_text.dn26:7.16: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returned to the royal capital. There it stood still by the gate to the royal compound at the High Court as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
translation_text.dn26:8.6: and a seventh time, a wheel-turning monarch was established in exactly the same way. And after many years the seventh wheel-turning monarch went forth, handing the realm over to the crown prince.
translation_text.dn26:8.18: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.
translation_text.dn26:9.1: Then a certain man approached the newly anointed aristocrat king and said,
translation_text.dn26:9.2: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’
translation_text.dn26:9.3: At that the king was unhappy and experienced unhappiness.
translation_text.dn26:9.4: But he didn’t go to the royal seer and ask about the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:9.5: He just governed the country according to his own ideas.
translation_text.dn26:9.6: So governed, the country’s people did not prosper like before, as they had when former kings proceeded in the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:9.7: Then the ministers and councillors, the finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, and professional advisers gathered and said to the king,
translation_text.dn26:9.8: ‘Sire, when governed according to your own ideas, the country’s people do not prosper like before, as they did when former kings proceeded in the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:9.9: In your realm are found ministers and councillors, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, and professional advisers—both ourselves and others—who remember the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:9.10: Please, Your Majesty, ask us about the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:10.1: So the anointed king asked the assembled ministers and councillors, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, and professional advisers about the noble duty of a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn26:10.3: After listening to them, he provided just protection and security. But he did not provide money to the penniless in the realm.
translation_text.dn26:10.5: When poverty was widespread, a certain person stole from others, with the intention to commit theft.
translation_text.dn26:10.7: and presented him to the king, saying,
translation_text.dn26:10.8: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others with the intention to commit theft.’
translation_text.dn26:10.9: The king said to that person,
translation_text.dn26:10.10: ‘Is it really true, worthy man, that you stole from others with the intention to commit theft?’
translation_text.dn26:10.14: So the king provided some money to that person, saying,
translation_text.dn26:10.15: ‘With this money, worthy man, keep yourself alive, and provide for your mother and father, partners and children. Work for a living, and establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.’
translation_text.dn26:11.1: But then another man stole something from others.
translation_text.dn26:11.3: and presented him to the king, saying,
translation_text.dn26:11.4: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’
translation_text.dn26:11.5: The king said to that person,
translation_text.dn26:11.6: ‘Is it really true, worthy man, that you stole from others?’
translation_text.dn26:11.10: So the king provided some money to that person, saying,
translation_text.dn26:11.11: ‘With this money, worthy man, keep yourself alive, and provide for your mother and father, partners and children. Work for a living, and establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.’
translation_text.dn26:12.2: ‘It seems the king is providing money to anyone who steals from others!’
translation_text.dn26:12.5: So then another man stole something from others.
translation_text.dn26:12.7: and presented him to the king, saying,
translation_text.dn26:12.8: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’
translation_text.dn26:12.9: The king said to that person,
translation_text.dn26:12.10: ‘Is it really true, worthy man, that you stole from others?’
translation_text.dn26:12.15: ‘If I provide money to anyone who steals from others, it will only increase the stealing.
translation_text.dn26:12.16: I’d better make an end of this person, finish him off, and chop off his head.’
translation_text.dn26:12.18: ‘Well then, my men, tie this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope. Shave his head and march him from street to street and square to square to the beating of a harsh drum. Then take him out the south gate and make an end of him, finish him off, and chop off his head.’
translation_text.dn26:12.19: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ they replied, and did as he commanded.
translation_text.dn26:13.2: ‘It seems the king is chopping the head off anyone who steals from others!’
translation_text.dn26:13.4: ‘We’d better have sharp swords made. Then when we steal from others, we’ll make an end of them, finish them off, and chop off their heads.’
translation_text.dn26:13.5: They had sharp swords made. Then they started to make raids on villages, towns, and cities, and to infest the highways.
translation_text.dn26:13.6: And they chopped the heads off anyone they stole from.
translation_text.dn26:14.1: And so, mendicants, from not providing money to the penniless, poverty became widespread. When poverty was widespread, theft became widespread. When theft was widespread, swords became widespread. When swords were widespread, killing living creatures became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom killing was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:14.2: Those people lived for 80,000 years, but their children lived for 40,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:14.3: Among the humans who lived for 40,000 years, a certain person stole something from others.
translation_text.dn26:14.5: and presented him to the king, saying,
translation_text.dn26:14.6: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’
translation_text.dn26:14.7: The king said to that person,
translation_text.dn26:14.8: ‘Is it really true, worthy man, that you stole from others?’
translation_text.dn26:15.1: And so, mendicants, from not providing money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, and killing became widespread. When killing was widespread, lying became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom lying was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:15.2: Those people who lived for 40,000 years had children who lived for 20,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:15.3: Among the humans who lived for 20,000 years, a certain person stole something from others.
translation_text.dn26:15.4: Someone else reported this to the king,
translation_text.dn26:15.5: ‘Your Majesty, such-and-such person stole from others,’ he said, going behind his back.
translation_text.dn26:16.1: And so, mendicants, from not providing money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, killing, and lying became widespread. When lying was widespread, backbiting became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom backbiting was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:16.2: Those people who lived for 20,000 years had children who lived for 10,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:17.1: Among the humans who lived for 10,000 years, some were beautiful, some were ugly.
translation_text.dn26:17.2: And the ugly beings, coveting the beautiful ones, committed adultery with the wives of others.
translation_text.dn26:17.3: And so, mendicants, from not providing money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, killing, lying, and backbiting became widespread. When backbiting was widespread, sexual misconduct became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom sexual misconduct was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:17.4: Those people who lived for 10,000 years had children who lived for 5,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:17.5: Among the humans who lived for 5,000 years, two things became widespread:
translation_text.dn26:17.7: For the sentient beings among whom these two things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:17.8: Those people who lived for 5,000 years had some children who lived for 2,500 years, while others lived for 2,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:17.9: Among the humans who lived for 2,500 years, desire and ill will became widespread.
translation_text.dn26:17.10: For the sentient beings among whom desire and ill will were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:17.11: Those people who lived for 2,500 years had children who lived for 1,000 years.
translation_text.dn26:17.12: Among the humans who lived for 1,000 years, wrong view became widespread.
translation_text.dn26:17.13: For the sentient beings among whom wrong view was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:17.14: Those people who lived for 1,000 years had children who lived for five hundred years.
translation_text.dn26:17.15: Among the humans who lived for five hundred years, three things became widespread:
translation_text.dn26:17.16: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong custom.
translation_text.dn26:17.17: For the sentient beings among whom these three things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:17.18: Those people who lived for five hundred years had some children who lived for two hundred and fifty years, while others lived for two hundred years.
translation_text.dn26:17.19: Among the humans who lived for two hundred and fifty years, these things became widespread:
translation_text.dn26:17.20: lack of due respect for mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and failure to honor the elders in the family.
translation_text.dn26:18.1: And so, mendicants, from not providing money to the penniless, all these things became widespread—poverty,
translation_text.dn26:18.11: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong custom,
translation_text.dn26:18.12: and lack of due respect for mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and failure to honor the elders in the family.
translation_text.dn26:18.13: For the sentient beings among whom these things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
translation_text.dn26:18.14: Those people who lived for two hundred and fifty years had children who lived for a hundred years.
translation_text.dn26:19.0: 5. When People Live for Ten Years
translation_text.dn26:19.1: There will come a time, mendicants, when these people will have children who live for ten years.
translation_text.dn26:19.2: Among the humans who live for ten years, girls will be marriageable at five.
translation_text.dn26:19.4: ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and salt.
translation_text.dn26:19.5: The best kind of food will be finger millet,
translation_text.dn26:19.6: just as fine rice with meat is the best kind of food today.
translation_text.dn26:19.8: The ten ways of doing skillful deeds will totally disappear, and the ten ways of doing unskillful deeds will explode in popularity.
translation_text.dn26:19.9: Those humans will not even have the word ‘skillful’, still less anyone who does what is skillful.
translation_text.dn26:19.10: And anyone who disrespects mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and fails to honor the elders in the family will be venerated and praised,
translation_text.dn26:19.11: just as the opposite is venerated and praised today.
translation_text.dn26:20.1: There’ll be no recognition of the status of mother, aunts, or wives and partners of tutors and respected people.
translation_text.dn26:20.2: The world will become dissolute, like goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and hounds and jackals.
translation_text.dn26:20.3: They’ll be full of hostility towards each other, with acute ill will, malevolence, and thoughts of murder.
translation_text.dn26:20.4: Even a mother will feel like this for her child, and the child for its mother,
translation_text.dn26:20.5: father for child, child for father,
translation_text.dn26:20.6: brother for sister, and sister for brother.
translation_text.dn26:20.7: They’ll be just like a deer hunter when he sees a deer—full of hostility, ill will, malevolence, and thoughts of killing.
translation_text.dn26:21.1: Among the humans who live for ten years, there will be an interregnum of swords lasting seven days.
translation_text.dn26:21.2: During that time they will see each other as beasts.
translation_text.dn26:21.3: Sharp swords will appear in their hands,
translation_text.dn26:21.4: with which they’ll take each other’s life, crying, ‘It’s a beast! It’s a beast!’
translation_text.dn26:21.5: But then some of those beings will think,
translation_text.dn26:21.6: ‘Let us neither kill nor be killed! Why don’t we hide in thick grass, thick jungle, thick trees, inaccessible riverlands, or rugged mountains and survive on forest roots and fruits?’
translation_text.dn26:21.8: When those seven days have passed, having emerged from their hiding places and embraced each other, they will come together and cry in one voice,
translation_text.dn26:21.9: ‘Fantastic, dear foe, you live! Fantastic, dear foe, you live!’
translation_text.dn26:21.12: ‘It’s because we undertook unskillful things that we suffered such an extensive loss of our relatives.
translation_text.dn26:21.14: What skillful thing should we do?
translation_text.dn26:21.15: Why don’t we refrain from killing living creatures? Having undertaken this skillful thing we’ll live by it.’
translation_text.dn26:21.17: Because of undertaking this skillful thing, their lifespan and beauty will grow.
translation_text.dn26:21.18: Those people who live for ten years will have children who live for twenty years.
translation_text.dn26:22.2: ‘Because of undertaking this skillful thing, our lifespan and beauty are growing.
translation_text.dn26:22.3: Why don’t we do even more skillful things?
translation_text.dn26:22.4: What skillful thing should we do?
translation_text.dn26:22.5: Why don’t we refrain from stealing …
translation_text.dn26:22.11: Why don’t we give up covetousness …
translation_text.dn26:22.15: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong custom.
translation_text.dn26:22.16: Why don’t we pay due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in our families? Having undertaken this skillful thing we’ll live by it.’
translation_text.dn26:22.18: Because of undertaking this skillful thing, their lifespan and beauty will grow.
translation_text.dn26:22.19: Those people who live for twenty years will have children who live for forty years.
translation_text.dn26:22.20: Those people who live for forty years will have children who live for eighty years,
translation_text.dn26:22.21: then a hundred and sixty years,
translation_text.dn26:23.3: Among the humans who live for 80,000 years, girls will be marriageable at five hundred.
translation_text.dn26:23.5: Among the humans who live for 80,000 years, there will be just three afflictions: greed, starvation, and old age.
translation_text.dn26:23.6: The Black Plum Tree Land will be successful and prosperous. The villages, towns, and capital cities will be no more than a chicken’s flight apart.
translation_text.dn26:23.7: And the land will be so full of humans you’d think they were squashed together, like a thicket of rushes or reeds.
translation_text.dn26:23.8: The royal capital will be Varanasi, renamed Ketumatī. And it will be successful, prosperous, populous, full of humans, with plenty of food.
translation_text.dn26:23.9: There will be 84,000 cities in the Black Plum Tree Land, with the royal capital of Ketumatī foremost.
translation_text.dn26:24.1: And in the royal capital of Ketumatī a king named Saṅkha will arise, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion will extend to all four sides, he will achieve stability in the country, and possess the seven treasures.
translation_text.dn26:24.2: He will have the following seven treasures:
translation_text.dn26:24.3: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
translation_text.dn26:24.4: He will have over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.dn26:24.5: After conquering this land girt by sea, he will reign by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.dn26:25.0: 8. The Arising of the Buddha Metteyya
translation_text.dn26:25.1: And the Blessed One named Metteyya will arise in the world—perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed—
translation_text.dn26:25.2: just as I have arisen today.
translation_text.dn26:25.3: He will realize with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and make it known to others, just as I do today.
translation_text.dn26:25.4: He will teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he will reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure,
translation_text.dn26:25.6: He will lead a Saṅgha of many thousand mendicants, just as I lead a Saṅgha of many hundreds today.
translation_text.dn26:26.1: Then King Saṅkha will have the sacrificial post once built by King Mahāpanāda raised up.
translation_text.dn26:26.2: Having reigned, he will abdicate, offering charity to ascetics and brahmins, paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars. Then, having shaved off his hair and beard and dressed in ocher robes, he will go forth from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha Metteyya’s presence.
translation_text.dn26:26.3: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, he will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He will live having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn26:27.1: Mendicants, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn26:27.2: And how does a mendicant do this?
translation_text.dn26:27.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn26:27.4: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.dn26:27.6: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn26:27.7: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how they let the teaching be their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn26:28.0: 9. On Long Life and Beauty for Mendicants
translation_text.dn26:28.1: Mendicants, you should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
translation_text.dn26:28.2: Doing so, you will grow in lifespan, beauty, happiness, wealth, and power.
translation_text.dn26:28.3: And what is long life for a mendicant?
translation_text.dn26:28.4: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.
translation_text.dn26:28.5: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.
translation_text.dn26:28.6: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.
translation_text.dn26:28.7: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.
translation_text.dn26:28.8: Having developed and cultivated these four bases of psychic power they may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn26:28.9: This is long life for a mendicant.
translation_text.dn26:28.10: And what is beauty for a mendicant?
translation_text.dn26:28.11: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
translation_text.dn26:28.12: This is beauty for a mendicant.
translation_text.dn26:28.13: And what is happiness for a mendicant?
translation_text.dn26:28.14: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn26:28.15: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.dn26:28.18: This is happiness for a mendicant.
translation_text.dn26:28.19: And what is wealth for a mendicant?
translation_text.dn26:28.20: It’s when a monk meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn26:28.21: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.dn26:28.23: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn26:28.24: This is wealth for a mendicant.
translation_text.dn26:28.25: And what is power for a mendicant?
translation_text.dn26:28.26: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn26:28.27: This is power for a mendicant.
translation_text.dn26:28.28: Mendicants, I do not see a single power so hard to defeat as the power of Māra.
translation_text.dn26:28.29: It is due to undertaking skillful qualities that merit grows.”
translation_text.dn26:28.30: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn26:28.31: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
